awd_titl_txt: ATD: Collaborative Research: Statistically Principled Real-Time Detection of Anomalies for Temporal Network Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The detection of anomalous events in time-evolving networks of interconnected entities is gaining importance in our increasingly connected world. Example applications of anomaly detection in this setting include detecting terrorist cells or hate groups in a social network, identifying over-burdened power plants in a power grid, and uncovering illegal activity in financial markets. A major benefit of casting these problems as anomaly detection in networks is the ability to leverage the underlying network structure to significantly improve detection power. This research aims to develop a framework for anomaly detection in networks that guarantees good detection performance.

This research aims to develop a two-stage pipeline for statistically-principled detection of anomalous events in static and dynamic networks. The first stage uses the structure and temporal evolution of the network to generate continually evolving time-series data for each node on the network. These multivariate time-series will be built out of a range of features, potentially including global information such as that from the spectral embedding and local information such as a nodes participation in subgraph patterns, or so-called "motifs". Part of this research is therefore necessarily developing efficient means to compute and update these features as the network evolves. The second stage leverages recent developments in robust statistics, especially multivariate quantile regression, to integrate side information and flag potential anomalies for further investigation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Modern data analysis is increasingly taking place on data that varies in time (e.g., connections being added or removed between individuals in a social network) and has network structure (e.g., the entities we are interested in studying are primarily described by their connections to others). For this type of data, one problem of particular interest is to determine when an "anomaly" occurs on the network. Anomalies can include things like abnormal communication patterns or finding outliers on the network. Moreover, it is important to detect them in real time as the data is being collected. The primary goal of this project was to develop principled methodologies for detecting and analyzing anomalies in time varying network data. 


This project resulted in several key outcomes that evolved our theoretical understanding of time evolving networks and produced novel algorithms to analyze real world data at the scale needed for applications of interest. To achieve this goal, the project had to devise good mathematical models for time evolving networks, understand how properties of networks change when connections are added/removed, build efficient algorithms for processing graph data, generalize methods to "higher order" network structures, and explore learning algorithms tailored to graphs. Collectively, these theoretical results and algorithms provide a foundational set of tools that can be used to analyze time evolving data and detect anomalies of various kinds in networks. Often, subsequent analysis is domain specific. Nevertheless, the tools here have been tested across a variety of example data sets and domains to ensure their broad applicability. The key outcomes are summarized below; other results developed under this project complement these primary developments.


The first key outcome of this project was the development of a mathematical model for so-called network interpolation. In order to study time evolving networks we require both real world data sets and concrete mathematical models we can use for analysis. This project produced a key result at the intersection of these demands. In particular, the resulting scheme leverages snapshots of existing network data to build complete, albeit fictitious, time histories for graphs. Connecting our mathematical models to real world networks ensures that they contain many of the features unique to real world data that is not necessarily well represented in common graph models.


A second fundamental thrust of this project centered around so-called spectral embeddings of graphs. Often, to study graphs it is vital to develop alternative representations for the data. Specifically, we want representations of the nodes (i.e., entities) of the network that encode key information about a given state of the graph. This process allows the use of more classical mathematical tools that do not naturally extend to the discrete setting of graphs (e.g., we only have nodes and edges). The projects key outcomes in this direction included foundational analysis of how these encodings change as the graph does (i.e., perturbation theory) and efficient algorithms for computing these embeddings as the graph evolves.


While the aforementioned embeddings are a key component of network analysis, often it is also important to characterize the graph in terms of its network structure. This necessistates the construction of efficient algorithms for counting structural properties of graphs (e.g., given a small subgraph, how often does it occur within a larger network). In fact, naive algorithms for this task are often too expensive to use in real time. This project produced several fast algorithms tailored to this task. Notably, they are well suited to maintaining information about the graph as it evolves (e.g., maintaining counts of the number of triangles in the network as edges are added and removed).


Given various metrics that quantify the graph, e.g., the aforementioned embeddings or quantifiers of discrete structure, it is necessary to extract and analyze anomalies. This project accomplishes this goal by considering several options. In particular, graph learning algorithms can be used to understand how data evolves on graphs. In additional, rational approximation methods are well suited to studying data that contains "shocks" as is often the case for anomalies. Such methods are also able to effectively localize sudden changes in underlying graph metrics. Lastly, this project started exploring properties of modern deep networks that may be well suited to anomaly detection given sufficient training data.
